'Equality, integrity and respect... unless you are Protestant, Unionist, British or Loyalist!!! No more pandering to Sinn F /IRA. No more concessons. Sinn F have had their terrorists released from prison, their murderers given letters of pardon/immunity/ amnesty, their bombers elevated to goverment while Protestants/Unionists have seen the total demise of the RUC, the UDR/RIR, orange parades prevented from exercising their democratic right to walk the Queens highway, orange halls attacked and burned, our protestant culture and heritage being demised day by day, hour by hour, police and prison officers being shot dead while Sinn F take our country to a political standstill while still accepting their pay in British pounds! Do not give them an inch. Stand your ground Arlene. We, the electorate gave you the mandate to run our government. No concessions to Sinn F /IRA terrorists.... not an inch!!!'

My mum and dad have also lived here for all of their lives and we are all Irish citizens. No matter how you dress it up, the land has always been Irish until the British stole it by force. There may be British rule now but they can't wait to get rid of NI. So bring on direct rule and we'll soon have a border poll."

"Hahahaha I did learn my history...seems you have a lot to learn. Ok so stealing may not be the correct word but taking it by force is all over the history books. I have read plenty. Actually I have no southern connections. This is the face of biternness and all that's wrong with this place. So what if I'm Irish and living in what I like to call the the North of Ireland. Live and let live. Continuously rubbing people up the wrong way is not the way to live life. I don't dispute you are British and I welcome the dual culture of this part of the country. People can and should live side by side and fly their flags side by side without hate. Obviously you have a problem with my views and nationality. The name is Ciara and not Clara."

"Ruby hanna you know us in England here look at the likes of you as Irish. 'Harry Topping Generally I take your point but when you mention history maybe a bit of clarification needed. Northern Ireland actually came into being in 1921, before the rest of Ireland seperated from the UK. The Irish state negotiated a seperation by a delegation from the illigitimate Sinn Fein Government. It was then passed by the Sinn Fein cabinate. It was also passed by the illigitimate Government in Dublin, as well as the legitimate Irish Parliament, the UK Westminster Government in Parliament and the UK House of Lords. The Irish Free State certainly had democratic legitimacy but it was not put to a vote for the whole population of the Irish Free State. The Irish Free State came into existance in 1922. Northern Ireland, having already been established with the consent of its people in 1921 was irrelevent to the Irish Free State decision. Although the Irish Free State electors did not have a referendum as such, they certainly overwhelmingly backed the politicians who set up the Irish Free State in the next election there.'

'Sorry your from America what would you know ,sort out your country before sticking your nose in ours thanks .No united Ireland .'
'Hahaha yes I was hoping you could explain your view point'
'Roger Fessenden its simple we want to remain British thats all...... its like asking a Chinese to be Dutch'
"I have a lot of questions but I'm really worries that they will all sound really stupid, I am very ignorant to the situation but I am also very interested."
'fire away Roger I,ll do my best to answer Iam a pensioner so I think Ive been around long enough to know the score as you younger generation would say Iam a silver surfer lol'
'Roger Fessenden Roger ask away'
'Thank you very much! And again I am so sorry these questions are going to be so dumb. So you live in northern Ireland? And do you consider your self English, Irish or both?'
"And are you Protestant I'm assuming?"
'yes Roger Iam a protestant I consider myself as being an Ulster woman'
'Would you like a United States of Canada ? Just thought I would ask'
'more seats maybe, but not FIRST MINISTER YET'
'looks like we are heading back to the troubles again that i thought we had left behind, for some people wont take this lying down. or could we end up in a civil war now??'

"Hetty Davis in all honesty I am already really enjoying talking to you. I was raised Irish Catholic and I've honestly never talked to a Protestant or even hardly talked to anyone from the north. Doesn't that sound so ignorant of me? I am a little embarrassed haha but this is really exciting for me. So to me Ulster is just a Providence of Ireland, however I imagine it is different to you? Concidering you see it as part of the UK? Walter Graham that is an interesting idea hahaha I guess it would be kind of like what you guys have... I don't know that I would necessarily hate it, however I can't imagine Canada wants to be part of America. Arlene Sloan yes the republic is not there yet. And as to the civil war comment my instinct is to say well certainly, we will get the Brits out by any means necessary however I am trying to look at it differently as it seems there are Irish in the north that like being part of the UK. Which leads me to ask if you consider your selves Irish? See that is very interesting to me because I've always believed that you couldn't possibly be Irish and part of the UK. I've lately talked in length to people in the republic who thought it was an absolutely atrocity for a Republican to vote in why they called a British election. And they actually really despise Sinn F ."

'Roger Fessenden yes Roger they do not like SF they never do well in the republic of Ireland elections I was reading the Sunday life paper yesterday and if you check it out they make it quite clear they want nothing to do with them. Its sad Roger you never spoke to protestant before now, I have many friends and actually relations who are catholic.s and have done so for many years .I think the catholic people in the north of Ireland know now they are better off being part of Britain and starting to change, .Roger the IRA did more to divide people than you can imagine it caused so much hatred, going up in the sixties as a young teenager I new nothing of catholic or protestants my parents brought the family up never talking about religion they too had catholic friends yes I was sent to Sunday school which now Iam so thankful for and we were poor but I loved my childhood exciting times then for me too as the Beatles had just came out lol so when the civil rights marches started and the IRA began their violence I was taken back at all this as I never could understand at first what it was all about but they really have alot to answer for.I also think the republic of Ireland dont want us I wish they could have a poll and ask them I would be interested to know, tell me something Roger where you brought up here ? and then moved to America'

"No sadly I wasn't, it was my grandmother who is the latest of my family to move to America and she won't talk about her child hood. Before that my grandfather knows he's Irish but hasn't said how far back they came over. My dad always taught us we where Irish but never explained politics or religion to us. I'm the only one in my immediate family who really cares to learn about that stuff. I've just never had the oppertunity, when ever I've met or talked to someone from Ireland they where from the republic and again never wanted to go into politics or anything. I've seen that, certainly agree that the IRA in the 70's 80's where awful. I always believed it was because Britain made them criminals and so they started to act like criminals. As a Republican and a person who hopes for Irish freedom I am very sorry for the way the IRA did things in the more recent years. My thoughts also have been compare 20 or so years of terror from the IRA to the 800 years of terror from England. I think it's easy for me to say we should have unity by any means however I am trying to change that view point and to be honest it was Sinn F who made me start to change that thought. Because they keep campaigning for equal rights for all Irish and I am working on realizing there are some Irish that don't want a united Ireland at this time and so I wanted to understand what the was that those people thought so we could move twords a united Ireland which would be good for all Irish."

"I think a lot of the people in the republic have that same mind set that we need unity at any cost. And that they haven't taken the step to wonder if that would be the best thing for all Irish. I talked to someone recently who said that the best sign of unity he'd seen was taking a gaelic class that had some unionist in it and seeing them start to embrace the language and the culture and each other and I thought we might ought to do the same thing. Try to understand where you guys come from because it would be us joining you as much as you joining us and I would want both sides to want the unity otherwise it's not really unity. It would almost be in my eyes the same thing the English did."

'Roger Fessenden well Roger the English owned all of Ireland to start with then the uprising happened and Ireland was given 26 counties and Ulster was formed but the IRA wanted it all they were never happy with this outcome.You could look at Ulster like the Scottish or Welsh who have their own identities but still part of the UK. I wouldn,t want an all Ireland and be under Rome and also I think we are much better off here but the ballot box is the only answer I go down south quite often and find the Irish people great people who just want to make a living I also think SF played on the Brexit vote as well and there is also more people of different nationalities here now too.But if an united Ireland came about civil war is not the answer'

"It's so hard for me to realize that anyone likes the English hahaha. Also since you mentioned it do you think the UK should go on with the Brexit? 'Roger Fessenden I dont know much about the Norman invasion in Ireland in the late 12th century just a bit but I know the British involvement was due to this and it took place in a matter of stages to long to explain anyway God has placed us where we are today you and I both so we have to make the best of our lives and what we have I dont want a united Ireland first because of the influence the Catholic church has over predominantly Catholic countries dont know if this is still the same nowadays in Ireland for I think people are changing second I do believe we are better off financially, you see I dont understand how Ireland voted for gay marriage when clearly the Catholic church is against this As for Brexit .I voted to leave the EU we did alright before we joined and I would like to get the chance to go it alone again there again it was up to the ballot box to decide and Iam glad we are leaving for we pour millions into the EU dont know how much we get back into the economy but a suppose time will tell if it was a good decision or not , Hope Iam answering all your questions Roger'

"You are. this is so wonderful for me I really appreciate the difference in view point it's so interesting. Also if you haven't read the Easter proclamation it's really a beautiful document to me I think there are a lot of people in the republic who need to read it and take it to hard there is a beautiful part that talks about equality that I think the world needs to read. In regards to the history I found a good video that explains it on YouTube a brief history of conflicts in the north that seemed to me refreshingly unbiased they didn't mention anything about the potato famine being genocide or the how the English transported a lot of innocent Irish to Australia or sold them as slaves to plantains in the Americas. However the video was good. As for the Brexit I hope for the best for Scotland, Wales and the north. If it's good for you then more power to it as you said we'll have to see what the polls say. Again thank you very much for your time like I said this is so wonderful and interesting to me, still a little confusing haha but it's really a learning experience."

"If you care to read my original post, I alluded to the fact that Ian paisley Snr stirred sectarian hatred and incited violence. I did not imply that he was the operating commander of any terrorist group. There is incontrovertible evidence of his toxic hate speech and actions as part of the various paramilitary organisations that he formed or was involved with. These include the Ulster Protestant Action, the Ulster Protestant Volunteers, Third force and the Ulster Resistance. Do you not know anything about Northern Irish history? This is all well documented, the speeches, pictures and film footage is all available online. I will give you a few examples to illustrate my point and you can decide if you still think that he was not responsible for inciting any violence or stirring sectarian tensions. I do however suggest that you do a bit more thorough reading about this. As part of the UPA, he was responsible for naming the addresses of catholic businesses and homes during a rally. These were later attacked and burnt out and 'taigs out' painted on their walls. He was also involved in campaigning for catholic families to be denied access to social housing. He formed the UPV, many of whose members were also in the UVF and who attended each other's marches and rallies. He publicly thanked the UVF for attending a march in 1966, shortly after which they launched an indiscrimate campaign of petrol bombing catholic homes and murdering innocent Catholics. In 1968 he roused a rabble of 500 men with cudgels to counter a civil rights march in Armagh. He was the main thrust of a workers strike which was aimed at paralysing the whole country for 2 weeks in 1974 in opposition to the sunningdale agreement. The strikers targeted fellow protestants who refused to stop working and culminated in loyalists bombing in Dublin and Monaghan, killing 33 innocent people. He later organised another strike in 1977, boasting that he had personally taken part in the patrols during a speech in Westminster. During this strike a loyalist bus driver was murdered for continuing to work and A UDR soldier was killed in a bomb targeted at a petrol station for staying open. Need I go on? (there is a LOT more) The point is, it stinks of hypocrisy for the DUP to go on saying that we need to teach our children that terrorism was never justified, when Paisley himself was responsible for inspiring some of that terrorism. You keep going back to mentioning other groups, who no doubt were at times equally or more responsible for the wrongs of the past. They seem to be trying to move forward. More than can be said for the DUP who Just want to keep dragging everyone back into the 'them and us' default setting. It's pathetic and embarrassing and anyone who considers voting for them should have a long hard look at themselves and their children and seriously consider if 'more of the same' is really going to help us all move on in peace and harmony"

"That's a more reasoned explanation than most, but I would add two major points. First, ideology is one source of motivation; accountability is another. "Every vote counts It's a FACT that around 50% of our population do not vote. If these people actually went out to vote this time around and voted for change, and returned candidates that advocate for actual change, then we might actually get change. It only takes around 20 mins to vote. So don't sit by idly this time round. If you don't vote out of protest. Protest by going to vote and by voting for change. Don't assume your single vote doesn't count, or that by voting for change you will be splitting the unionist vote. THIS IS NOT THE CASE. As Northern Ireland uses the STV (Single Transferable Vote) system to vote in elections, actually means we have a choice when it comes to voting. eg. Say you are fed up of voting DUP and want to give another party a chance like your Traditional Unionist Voice candidate. Give your TUV candidate your number 1 vote. Then if you wish vote DUP (2) UUP (3) Ukip (4) and so on. If your TUV candidate (your number 1 vote) does not make the count, your vote will be transferred to DUP (your number 2 vote). Therefore NOT WASTING YOUR VOTE at all but maximising your CHOICE. This process will continue until all your preferences have been used. The myth of splitting the Unionist vote is a ploy by the largest Unionist party to make people worried about SF becoming the largest party, making people vote for them. This was brought about by the DUP during the st Andrews agreement. So MAKE SURE YOU'RE REGISTERED TO VOTE today. Use your vote this time round. No other option will ever bring change. #wantCHANGE #vote4CHANGE"

'Brexit The young, the educated, the Londoners, the Scots, the Welsh, the Northern Irish, the Irish, Cypriots and Maltese must vote to remain If Britain chooses to withdraw from the European Union, it will bring to an end a tempestuous relationship between the individualist leaning Brits and more Communatarian rest of the continent. Within Britain it is clear that strong majorities exist for remaining in the EU in Scotland and in Northern Ireland and to a lesser extent in Wales. Digging deeper, London wishes strongly to remain and the rest of England slightly to strongly negative. Poor little England. What is astonishing is that, in England, those regions that are least affected by the migration which is portrayed as the catalyst of this crisis, are the most vehement in their refusal to consider reasoned argument on the subject. London, a vibrant and international city, full of migrants, is the most positive part of England in favour of remaining in Europe. Despite the 2011 census showing its ethnic makeup is less than 45% British (which includes Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland), far from feeling threatened by diversity, the English capital clearly does not share UKIPs view that England would be better off out. This most densely populated part of England does not feel there is a lack of space or jobs and does not see its culture threatened by migrants. Comparing the capital to the rural counties from where distressing reports of the abuse of migrant workers emerge regularly, we already have a feeling that the contradictory views and behaviour of the leave-shires lack morality whichever way we look at them. The antics of Boris Johnson who has, with great energy to give him his due, taken over from the political fringe occupied by the failed UKIP party in flying the Leave flag and are an embarrasment. The unavoidable comparisons with the other blonde mop-top go deeper than dodgy hair styles. While Trump is out to buy the US presidency with money and barely disguised gung-ho racism, Johnson, having lost his position as Mayor of London clearly sees an opportunity in the Leave campaign to challenge for ladership of the Tory party and a path to being Prime Minister. That alone should be enough to ring alarm bells regarding his judgement of whats best for Britain. The narrow education that is typical in English schools, where the majority of young people do not learn a foreign language, or economics, or geography, or history to the A levels, creates a fertile ground for those who wish to spread untruth, myths and outrageous lies about the European project. It is imperfect. So is the British take on democracy. But it has delivered peace, growth, freedom of movement and human rights. It is has had a mondernising and positive influence on every country it has touched. Yes there are differences of approach and views and yes it sometimes takes years to arrive at less than perfect compromises. But it does achiecve that, where otherwise there would be nothing. If the UK drops out of Europe, where will the Foreign Direct Investment to Britain go? We can expect a certain amount to go there regardless, but a large part of that investment is prdicated on the UK providing access to the EU market with tarifs or trade barriers. It is also predicated on the current situation where the pound does not swing wildly relative to the Euro. Ireland and the Netherlands seem likely targets for companies. As the OECD reports, (http://www.oecd.org/daf/inv/investment-policy/FDI-in-Figures-April-2016.pdf) "OECD FDI inflows almost doubled compared to 2014, most ly due to large inflows in Ireland, the Netherlands , Switzerland and the United States . Investors from those countries were also responsible for the 35 % increase in OECD outflows. These countries appear among the top destinations and top sources of FDI worldwide in 2015." It cannot be a good thing for the UK to become less attractive as a destination for investment just as it chooses to go it alone. And that\'s the nub of it. If Britain votes to leave the EU, they will be alone. Remaining a member of NATO will not keep people in jobs, or ensure British exports have free access to the single biggest market in the world. Everyone who\'s opinion is based on science rather than emotion agrees from UK based business leaders, politicans from all parties except UKIP and the DUP, trade unions, economic forecasters and academics. The wider world\'s most respected and influential economic organisations and leaders are of one voice - to leave would be anything from foolish to disastrous. Even President Obama, who\'s office would not usually pronounce on such sovereign discussions has made clear that this would damage the UKs position with the US. In fact, internationally, the US mop-head Trump appears to be Johnson\'s only ally there. How long before he suggests that he will flood the Channel Tunnel and make the French pay for it? Even the citizens of Europe are, in every other EU country positive they want the UK to remain. Johnson\'s charge that there is a \'democratic void\' in Europe is worth discussing, but so to is the faulty democracry present in many EU states, the UK included, where winning as little as 38% of the vote can lead to overwhelming majorities in our nations parliaments. That is a subject for another day. For now, let us hope that the young, the educated, the Londoners, the Scots, the Welsh, the Northern Irish, the Irish, Cypriots and Maltese in Britain all come out in vast numbers because they are the ones who can ensure a positive result for Britain, for Ireland and for Europe - a continent united. If you know anyone with a vote - encourage them to vote to remain. Anything else would be very bad for the UK. TDH'

"I think it's obvious why the DUP favours exit, it strengthens the principle of existence of the border. In England the Outers have their own agenda. '1. The EU is not a sovereign entity. It has only the powers that we give it. 2. Westminster is the supreme law making authority in this country. 3. In cases where EU law is given priority over domestic law in our courts, it is only because the UK parliament has expressly instructed them to do so in our own legislation. 4. Membership of the EU entails certain obligations but it also offers the opportunity to influence decision making on the world stage. 5. The UK has enormous influence within the EU. It is not something that happens TO us. We are major players. In practice, nothing happens within the EU to which we are not party. 6. We have two years to sever ties with the EU, in the event of an exit win. But future relations with the EU is a separate thing in terms of things like trade, travel, and legal agreements. EU legal experts say typically it takes at least ten years just to get to a basic agreement. 7. The "Norwegian Model" of EU market membership without EU membership is not necessarily available to us. Even if it is, it is very expensive. We will have a huge number of rules to follow without any ability to influence what those rules are. 8. It is completely beyond doubt that a vote to leave the EU we will terminate ALL trade agreements with countries out-with the EU, as those were negotiated via the EU. This will entail renegotiating around 70 trade agreements. 9. Several countries have said they do not want to negotiate a new trade agreement with the UK until they know the terms of our new trade agreement with the EU. (The one that will take an estimated ten years. This is the official, public position of the USA and China.'
